title: 107_hr1687
content: The Act may be cited as the "Poverty Trap Study Act of 2001". Congress finds that low income individuals are burdened by various taxes and face high effective marginal tax rates, which can discourage them from working more, getting raises, or improving their skills. This can also impact their eligibility for federal and state assistance programs. Low income individuals may face high taxes and marginal tax rates, which can discourage them from advancing their skills or engaging in economic activities like getting married. The National Commission on Marginal Tax Rates for the Working Poor is established to address high taxes and marginal tax rates that discourage low-income individuals from advancing their skills or engaging in economic activities like getting married. The National Commission on Marginal Tax Rates for the Working Poor is established to determine total effective marginal tax rates for individuals and married couples earning between $7,000 and $30,000 per year in at least 5 states, including Wisconsin and California. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Minority Leader. The National Commission on Marginal Tax Rates for the Working Poor consists of 12 members appointed by various leaders. The Commission members will elect a chairman at their first meeting and must include recognized experts in the subject matter. Appointments to the Commission are for the life of the Commission. The National Commission on Marginal Tax Rates for the Working Poor consists of 12 members appointed by various leaders. The Commission members will elect a chairman at their first meeting and must include recognized experts in the subject matter. Appointments to the Commission are for the life of the Commission. Meetings will be called by the designated member or Chairman, with a quorum of 7 members required. Vacancies will be filled promptly, and members will not receive additional compensation for their service. The National Commission on Marginal Tax Rates for the Working Poor consists of 12 members appointed by various leaders. The Commission members will elect a chairman at their first meeting and must include recognized experts in the subject matter. Appointments are for the life of the Commission. Meetings will be called by the designated member or Chairman, with a quorum of 7 members required. Vacancies will be filled promptly, and members will not receive additional compensation for their service. Each member of the Commission shall receive travel expenses and per diem in accordance with regulations. The Chairman appoints an executive director who is paid at the rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The executive director may appoint staff with the approval of the Commission. Staff appointments are made without regard to civil service laws. The Commission members are appointed without regard to competitive service rules and paid without following General Schedule pay rates. The executive director can hire temporary services with approval. The Administrator of General Services will provide office space and equipment for the Commission's headquarters. The Commission may hold hearings, request studies by the Comptroller General, and request federal employees to assist in carrying out its duties. The Commission may request technical assistance from Federal agencies and use the United States mails for communication. It can also obtain necessary information directly from Federal agencies to carry out its duties. The Commission can request information from Federal agencies under section 552 of title 5, United States Code. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services upon request. The Commission will be treated as a committee of Congress for printing costs. A report must be submitted to Congress within one year of the Act's enactment. The Commission established by the Act will submit a report to Congress with findings and recommendations on economic disincentives caused by marginal tax rates for the working poor. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the report, and there is a limit of $900,000 for appropriations.
